content.description: <math alttext="The figure presents a 4 column table, with 1 row of data. The data in the table are as follows. Column 1, f of negative 2, equals 3. Column 2, f prime of negative 2, equals 4. Column 3, g of 4, equals 5. Column 4, g prime of 4, equals 2." display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable columnlines="solid" columnspacing="0em" columnwidth="6em 6em 6em 6em" equalrows="false" frame="solid" framespacing="0em 1em" rowlines="solid" rowspacing="0em" width="auto"><mtr><mtd><mi>f</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>4</mn></mtd><mtd><mi>g</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></mtd><mtd><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: The point <math alttext="with coordinates negative 2 comma 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> lies on the curve in the <math alttext="x y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane given by the equation <math alttext="f of x, times, g of y, equals, 17 minus x, minus y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mi>f</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mi>g</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>17</mn><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a differentiable function of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is a differentiable function of <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Selected values of <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="f prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>f</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="g" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="g prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table above. What is the value of <math alttext="the derivative of y, with respect to x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> at the point <math alttext="with coordinates negative 2 comma 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><mo>,</mo><mn>4</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions

skill.text: Skill 1.E: Apply appropriate mathematical rules or procedures, with and without technology.
